Introduction

Since my childhood, I've frequently encountered phrases incorporating the word "time". One classic expression that was echoed by various adults was: "the time is over". Another, a more poetic rendering, often heard among people (Rodrigues, W., Soares Filho, A. C., Vale, M. S. do, & Menezes, M. C., 2023, pp. 12):

• The time asked for time: what time does time possess?
    The time responded, it does not have time to say
    the remaining time within time is the time available.

If you've had any involvement with 'Abrahamic religions' (Guy G. Stroumsa, 2011) at any point in your life, you might be familiar with Ecclesiastes chapter 3, which states that there is a "time for every pursuit under the heavens", illustrated with examples of different periods of time (Torah, Neviim u-Khetuvim. Twenty-four books of the Holy Scriptures carefully translated according to the Massoretic text, on the basis of the English version, after the best Jewish authorities, 1891, pp. 876 - 877 ).

Reflexion 1: A question
All the preceding references have one thing in common: they allude to time, yet none offers a precise definition. So, what exactly is time?
